dt: {bc}a yellow metallic element that occurs naturally in pure form and is used especially in coins, jewelry, and electronics {dx}see {dxt|Chemical Elements Table|element|table}{/dx}
{bc}something valued as the finest of its kind
{bc}a medal awarded as the first prize in a competition {bc}a gold medal

et: Middle English, going back to Old English, neuter strong noun, going back to Germanic {it}*gulþa-/*gulđa-{/it} (with varying accentuation, whence also Old Frisian, Old Saxon, and Old High German {it}gold{/it} "gold," Old Norse {it}gull, goll,{/it} Gothic {it}gulþ{/it}), going back to dialectal Indo-European {it}*ǵhl̥(h{inf}3{/inf})-to-,{/it} with full-grade ablaut {it}*ǵhel(h{inf}3{/inf})-to-{/it} (in Latvian {it}zȩ̀lts{/it} "gold," Old Prussian {it}sealtmeno{/it} "oriole") and o-grade {it}*ǵhol(h{inf}3{/inf})-to-{/it} (in Slavic {it}*zȍlto,{/it} whence Old Church Slavic {it}zlato{/it} "gold," Bosnian-Croatian-Serbian {it}zlâto,{/it} Polish {it}złoto,{/it} Russian {it}zóloto{/it}), all derivatives with the adjectival suffix {it}*-to-{/it} from Indo-European {it}*ǵhelh{inf}3{/inf}-{/it} "yellow, green" {ma}{mat|yellow:1|}{/ma}

The formation of a word for "gold" from a {it}*-to-{/it} derivative of Indo-European {it}*ǵhelh{inf}3{/inf}-{/it} "yellow, green" is peculiar to Germanic, Slavic, and, in part, Baltic. An Indo-Iranian word for "gold" is formed with different suffixation from the same root: {it}*ǵhl̥h{inf}3{/inf}-en-i̯o-,{/it} whence Sanskrit {it}híranya-{/it} "gold," Avestan {it}zarańiia-.{/it} A full display of forms in medieval and modern languages and loans into non-Indo-European languages is contained in the article "Indo-European 'Gold' in Time and Space" by Václav Blažek, {it}Journal of Indo-European Studies,{/it} vol. 45, No. 3 (fall/winter 2017), pp. 267-311.
shortdef: a yellow metallic element that occurs naturally in pure form and is used especially in coins, jewelry, and electronics

dt: {bc}to have enough sales to qualify for a gold record
{bc}a person whose romantic pursuit of, relationship with, or marriage to a wealthy person is primarily or solely motivated by a desire for money

dt.t: Whether you're dating a potential {wi}gold digger{/wi} or are surrounded by friends who are constantly asking for handouts, you'll want to protect your money from those kinds of drains.

For years, it has almost always played out like this: A woman accuses a famous man of harassment, and that famous man calls her a liar. The media reports it, expensive lawyers rush in to also call the woman a liar and maybe a {wi}gold digger{/wi} and maybe worse …
To deflect the impression that he was a {wi}gold digger{/wi} par excellence, Bingham renounced any claim on his new wife's fortune.

shortdef: a person whose romantic pursuit of, relationship with, or marriage to a wealthy person is primarily or solely motivated by a desire for money

dt: {bc}consisting of a base metal covered with a layer of gold

shortdef: consisting of a base metal covered with a layer of gold

dt: {bc}an extremely thin sheet of gold that is used especially for gilding

shortdef: an extremely thin sheet of gold that is used especially for gilding
a rich source of something desired

dt: {bc}a European herb ({it}Camelina sativa{/it}) of the mustard family that is cultivated for its oil-rich seeds

shortdef: a European herb (Camelina sativa) of the mustard family that is cultivated for its oil-rich seeds

dt: {bc}a gold phonograph record awarded to a singer or group whose single record or album has sold at least 500,000 copies

shortdef: a gold phonograph record awarded to a singer or group whose single record or album has sold at least 500,000 copies

dt: {bc}a rush to newly discovered goldfields in pursuit of riches
{bc}the headlong pursuit of sudden wealth in a new or lucrative field

shortdef: a rush to newly discovered goldfields in pursuit of riches
the headlong pursuit of sudden wealth in a new or lucrative field
